content: The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is part of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, amending Part B to establish technology innovation awards for schools. The purpose of the "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" is to expand knowledge about advanced computers and telecommunications for teaching, address national questions about technology in education, and develop innovative models for widespread adoption in schools. The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" aims to develop innovative models of technology applications for teaching and learning, aligned with academic standards, for adoption by educational agencies. The "Next Generation Technology Innovation Awards Act of 2000" authorizes the Secretary to award grants for the development of technology applications aligned with academic standards. The Secretary can award grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements through the Office of Educational Technology for up to 5 years on a competitive basis. "SEC. 3212. ELIGIBILITY for grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements through the Office of Educational Technology for up to 5 years on a competitive basis." Eligible applicants for grants under this part must be a consortium including a State or local educational agency and an institution of higher education, for-profit entity, museum, library, or other entity with expertise to support educational agencies. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. To receive a grant under this part, eligible applicants must submit an application to the Secretary, including a project description and a plan for independent project evaluation with specific objectives and benchmarks. The Secretary may require applicants to submit a detailed plan for the independent evaluation of the proposed project, including benchmarks to monitor progress towards specific objectives. Priorities for awards may include projects developing innovative models for educational technology use. The Secretary may establish priorities for awards under this part, including innovative models of educational technology use, projects serving multiple states with large-scale innovations, and projects developing innovative technologies. Priority for projects may include serving multiple states with large-scale innovations in technology use in education, developing innovative models for underserved populations, and providing substantial financial and other resources to achieve project goals. Priority for projects includes serving traditionally underserved populations like low-income students, students with disabilities, and students with limited English proficiency. Additionally, priorities are given to projects that provide substantial financial resources, develop innovative models for using electronic networks, and establish high-speed internet access. "SEC. 3213. USES OF FUNDS." "A recipient must use funds awarded under this part to develop new educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and carry out other related activities." The recipient must use funds to develop educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and conduct other related activities, including innovative models for teacher professional development. The recipient must use funds to develop educational technologies, integrate technology across the curriculum, and conduct innovative models for teacher professional development, including creating high-quality digital content. The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, and web-based resources in new technological formats to facilitate better subject matter understanding in challenging learning environments. This includes computer modeling, visualization, and simulation tools. The recipient must use funds to develop high-quality digital content, including multimedia software, digital video, and web-based resources in new technological formats to facilitate better subject matter understanding in challenging learning environments, such as physics, foreign languages, or Advanced Placement courses. This includes computer modeling, visualization, and simulation tools, new methods for assessing student performance, and web-based distance learning curricula. This includes computer modeling, visualization, and simulation tools, new methods for assessing student performance, web-based and distance learning curricula, learning-focused digital libraries, information retrieval systems, and software supporting the development of learning content. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings to evaluate activities assisted under this part. The Secretary is authorized to develop tools, provide resources, offer technical assistance, conduct independent evaluations, and disseminate findings to evaluate activities assisted under this part, including promoting effective models for evaluating the impact of educational technology on teaching and learning. The recipient of funds under this part is limited to using no more than 3 percent of the funds for administrative costs or technical assistance. The Secretary may require recipients of awards to share in the cost of assisted activities, up to 50% of the total cost. The non-Federal share may be in cash or in-kind contributions, and can be increased after the first year of receiving funds. The Secretary must publish notice in the Federal Register. The non-Federal share required for an award under this part cannot exceed 50% of the activity cost. The Secretary will publish the non-Federal share in the Federal Register.
